A New York man who was e1:accused of e2:faking his e2012:death last summer e3:pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday, Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice e5:announced.

Raymond Roth, 48, of Massapequa, New York, was first e6:reported e7:missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year-old son, Jonathan Roth. Several days into an extensive e8:search involving multiple agencies, New York State Park Police e9:said, authorities e10:learned the missing man was in South Carolina, where he had been e11:pulled over for e1000:speeding.

The day before Raymond Roth was e12:pulled over, his wife, Evana, e13:showed authorities e-mails she had e14:discovered that e15:appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to e2001:fake his e16:death. Raymond Roth e17:wanted his wife and son to e18:collect at least $410,000 in life insurance benefits while he e19:started a new life in Florida, Rice e20:said.

State police e21:arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud, conspiracy and filing a false report. Raymond Roth on Thursday e23:agreed to e24:plead guilty to the conspiracy e25:charge in exchange for a e26:sentence of 90 days in jail and five years' probation, the district attorney's office e27:said. He also must e28:pay restitution for the cost of the e29:search -- $27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department.

Evana Roth e30:told CNN in August she e31:thought her husband e32:devised the plan after he was e33:fired from his job in July. Her attorney, Lenard Leeds, e34:said she had been e2003:unaware of the e35:ruse before she e36:uncovered the e-mail e1001:correspondence.

"There needs to be a way for me to e37:find out how things are e38:going. e39:Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort," Raymond Roth e40:wrote in an e-mail to his son the day before the son e41:reported him e42:missing.

The son's case is still e43:pending, the district attorney e44:said. Jonathan Roth's attorney, Joey Jackson, e45:defended his client after his e46:arrest, e47:saying, "There was e2005:abuse here, e2006:manipulation here, e2007:coercion here" from the father.

Raymond Roth's attorney, Brian Davis, e48:denied in August that Roth had e49:involved his son in the scheme.

"We had e2008:issues concerning the facts people had whether (Roth) had an e2009:agreement with his son," Davis e50:told CNN on Thursday. "He's e51:admitted it now. He's e52:accepted responsibility."

Davis e53:added that his client has been under e2010:treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks.

During plea e54:negotiations, Raymond Roth e55:asked the district attorney's office not to e56:give his son jail time, Davis e57:said.

On the advice of both their attorneys, father and son have not been in e2011:contact since their e58:arrests, Davis e59:said.

"He would e60:like to e61:straighten things out with (Jonathan) when the time e62:comes," he e63:said.

text:
Health insurers are privately e1:warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could e2:increase sharply next year because of the health-care overhaul law, with the nation's biggest firm e2002:projecting that rates could more than e3:double for some consumers buying their own plans.

The projections, made in e5:sessions with brokers and agents, provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might e6:increase prices when major provisions of the law e7:kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate.

The projected e8:increases are at odds with what the Obama Administration e9:says consumers should be e10:expecting overall in terms of cost. The Department of Health and Human Services e11:says that the law will "e12:make health-care coverage more e2000:affordable and e2001:accessible," e13:pointing to a 2009 e38:analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that e14:says average individual premiums, on an apples-to-apples basis, would be lower.

The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections e16:suggests how e40:complicated the law's effects will be. Carriers will be e17:filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months.

Part of the murkiness e18:stems from the role of government subsidies. Federal subsidies under the health law will e19:help lower-income consumers e20:defray costs, but they are generally not included in insurers' premium projections. Many consumers will be e21:getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law. The effects of the law will e22:vary widely, and insurers and other analysts e23:agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go e24:down.

e25:Starting next year, the law will e26:block insurers from e27:refusing to e28:sell coverage or e29:setting premiums based on people's health histories, and will e30:reduce their ability to set rates based on age. That can e32:raise coverage prices for younger, healthier consumers, while e33:reining them in for older, sicker ones. The rules can also e34:affect small businesses, which sometimes e35:pay premiums tied to employees' health status and claims history.

Health insurers are privately e1:warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could e2:increase sharply next year because of the health-care overhaul law, with the nation's biggest firm e2002:projecting that rates could more than e3:double for some consumers buying their own plans.

The projections, made in e5:sessions with brokers and agents, provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might e6:increase prices when major provisions of the law e7:kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate.

The projected e8:increases are at odds with what the Obama Administration e9:says consumers should be e10:expecting overall in terms of cost. The Department of Health and Human Services e11:says that the law will "e12:make health-care coverage more e2000:affordable and e2001:accessible," e13:pointing to a 2009 e38:analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that e14:says average individual premiums, on an apples-to-apples basis, would be lower.

The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections e16:suggests how e40:complicated the law's effects will be. Carriers will be e17:filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months.

Part of the murkiness e18:stems from the role of government subsidies. Federal subsidies under the health law will e19:help lower-income consumers e20:defray costs, but they are generally not included in insurers' premium projections. Many consumers will be e21:getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law. The effects of the law will e22:vary widely, and insurers and other analysts e23:agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go e24:down.

e25:Starting next year, the law will e26:block insurers from e27:refusing to e28:sell coverage or e29:setting premiums based on people's health histories, and will e30:reduce their ability to set rates based on age. That can e32:raise coverage prices for younger, healthier consumers, while e33:reining them in for older, sicker ones. The rules can also e34:affect small businesses, which sometimes e35:pay premiums tied to employees' health status and claims history.

text:
The flu e1000028:season is winding down, and it has e2:killed 105 children so far - about the average toll.

The season e3:started about a month earlier than usual, e4:sparking concerns it might e5:turn into the worst in a decade. It e6:ended up being very hard on the elderly, but was moderately severe overall, e7:according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Six of the pediatric e1000030:deaths were e8:reported in the last week, and it's possible there will be more, e9:said the CDC's Dr. Michael Jhung e10:said Friday.

Roughly 100 children e11:die in an average flu season. One exception was the swine flu e1000032:pandemic of 2009-2010, when 348 children e12:died.

The CDC e13:recommends that all children ages 6 months and older be e2001:vaccinated against flu each season, though only about half get a flu shot or nasal spray.

All but four of the children who e16:died were old enough to be e17:vaccinated, but 90 percent of them did not get e19:vaccinated, CDC officials e20:said.

This year's vaccine was e21:considered effective in children, though it didn't e22:work very well in older people. And the dominant flu strain early in the e2002:season was one that tends to cause more severe illness.

The government only does a national flu death count for children. But it does track hospitalization rates for people 65 and older, and those statistics have been e1000033:grim.

In that group, 177 out of every 100,000 were e26:hospitalized with flu-related illness in the past several months. That's more than 2 1/2 times higher than any other recent season.

This flu e2003:season e27:started in early December, a month earlier than usual, and e1000035:peaked by the end of year. Since then, flu reports have been e28:dropping off throughout the country.

"We e29:appear to be e30:getting close to the end of flu e2004:season," Jhung e31:said.

The season e3:started about a month earlier than usual, e4:sparking concerns it might e5:turn into the worst in a decade. It e6:ended up being very hard on the elderly, but was moderately severe overall, e7:according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Six of the pediatric e1000030:deaths were e8:reported in the last week, and it's possible there will be more, e9:said the CDC's Dr. Michael Jhung e10:said Friday.

Roughly 100 children e11:die in an average flu season. One exception was the swine flu e1000032:pandemic of 2009-2010, when 348 children e12:died.

The CDC e13:recommends that all children ages 6 months and older be e2001:vaccinated against flu each season, though only about half get a flu shot or nasal spray.

All but four of the children who e16:died were old enough to be e17:vaccinated, but 90 percent of them did not get e19:vaccinated, CDC officials e20:said.

This year's vaccine was e21:considered effective in children, though it didn't e22:work very well in older people. And the dominant flu strain early in the e2002:season was one that tends to cause more severe illness.

The government only does a national flu death count for children. But it does track hospitalization rates for people 65 and older, and those statistics have been e1000033:grim.

In that group, 177 out of every 100,000 were e26:hospitalized with flu-related illness in the past several months. That's more than 2 1/2 times higher than any other recent season.

This flu e2003:season e27:started in early December, a month earlier than usual, and e1000035:peaked by the end of year. Since then, flu reports have been e28:dropping off throughout the country.

"We e29:appear to be e30:getting close to the end of flu e2004:season," Jhung e31:said.

text:
A Cyprus e2001:exit from the euro union, if it e1:comes to that, would have a devastating e2023:effect on the country's citizens, who are among the most e2006:indebted in the euro zone. And for European unity and diplomacy, the Cyprus e2102:debacle has already been at least a short-term e2007:disaster.

ut for the broader financial system in Europe, the losses e2:resulting from a Cypriot banking e2105:collapse and the country's e3:return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the e4:havoc that Greece would have e5:created had it not been e6:bailed out.

And that, economists and investors e7:contend, is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers, were so e2008:adamant that depositors - large and small, Cypriot and Russian - e2009:contribute 5.8 billion euros ($7.5 billion) toward the 10 billion euro e2103:bailout of Cyprus's largest banks.

Greece may well have been too big to e8:fail last year, but Cyprus, which e9:creates less than one-half percent of the euro zone's gross domestic product, is certainly not.

From a financial standpoint, what is most e2012:noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people, companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country's gross domestic product. Only Ireland, still e10:struggling to e11:recover from the banking e2013:collapse that required an international e12:bailout in 2010, has a higher debt-to-G.D.P. e2106:ratio among euro zone countries.

As debts in Europe e13:mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens, companies and governments to e14:make good on them, the view is e15:forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be e16:sent that citizens and investors must e17:start accepting e2014:losses for the euro zone to e19:survive in the long run.

"There have been too many bailouts in Europe; it's time to e20:remove the air bags," e21:said Stephen Jen, a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London. "This is not a Lehman," he e22:said, e23:referring to the disastrous chain e2100:reaction e24:touched off by the e2016:collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008.

Eric Dor is a French economist who has e25:studied the mechanics of how a country might e26:remove itself from the monetary union. By his calculations, the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit e27:exposure to Cyprus. That is a mere rounding error compared with the euro zone G.D.P. of 9.4 trillion euros.

Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been e30:forced into a disorderly euro e2011:exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros, given the larger e32:exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country.

"This e33:explains why Germany and others are putting so much e34:pressure on Cyprus," e35:said Mr. Dor, head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille, France. "They are e36:saying we can take the risk of e38:pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone, and that Europe can take the e39:losses without going e40:broke."

Mr. Dor e41:notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was e42:put in place after the financial e2017:panic that followed the Lehman e43:collapse. Those deposits are e44:supposed to be e45:insured by national governments.

So when the president of Cyprus e46:admitted this week that his country did not e2104:have the money to backstop the 30 billion euros of guaranteed bank deposits - a figure greater than the Cypriot economy itself - a crucial bond of trust between a government and its citizens was e47:snapped.

"It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has e48:admitted that he could not e49:afford to e50:pay the guarantee," Mr. Dor e51:said.

A hasty e52:expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more e2101:evanescent, once they are e55:converted back into Cypriot pounds, the currency Cyprus used before e57:adopting the euro in 2007.

ut for the broader financial system in Europe, the losses e2:resulting from a Cypriot banking e2105:collapse and the country's e3:return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the e4:havoc that Greece would have e5:created had it not been e6:bailed out.

Greece may well have been too big to e8:fail last year, but Cyprus, which e9:creates less than one-half percent of the euro zone's gross domestic product, is certainly not.

From a financial standpoint, what is most e2012:noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people, companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country's gross domestic product. Only Ireland, still e10:struggling to e11:recover from the banking e2013:collapse that required an international e12:bailout in 2010, has a higher debt-to-G.D.P. e2106:ratio among euro zone countries.

An hour before her colleagues e1000009:gathered for their first e1:vote of a new Congress, Senator Kelly Ayotte e2:slipped into an empty Senate chamber to e3:savor the grandeur of her legislative home. As Ms. Ayotte, a freshman Republican from New Hampshire, e4:sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had e5:cast their votes, a doorman e6:marched toward her with purpose.

The desks, he sternly e7:told her, were for senators only.

Ms. Ayotte's e1000010:induction that January day in 2011 into the most rarefied ranks of the nation's political class, female senators, had e8:begun. "The desk thing really e9:stuck with me," Ms. Ayotte e10:said. "There still just aren't that many of us."

In the 90 years since Rebecca Felton of Georgia e11:became the first woman in the United States Senate - e12:sworn in for a mere 24 hours - women e13:remain an anomaly in the upper chamber. But with 20 female senators now in e1000011:office, an all-time high, women have e1000012:morphed from the e1010:curiosity they were for much of the 20th century into an important new force on key committees and legislation.

A record nine women now lead committees, including some of the most powerful ones. For the first time there is a woman - Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat - in charge of the Senate Appropriations Committee, which e14:dispenses billions of dollars annually throughout the government and has long been particularly e15:dominated by men. Senator Patty Murray, a Washington Democrat, is the first chairwoman of the Budget Committee and is e16:charged with e17:shaping the Democratic strategy in the fiscal e18:battle dominating Capitol Hill.

One of the biggest bills to e19:pass the Senate last year was farm legislation e20:led by Senator Debbie Stabenow, a Michigan Democrat who e21:presides over the agriculture committee. Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat who is chairwoman of the Environment and Public Works Committee, e22:shepherded the highway bill.

"We are e23:growing in number," e24:said Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota. "But more importantly, we are e25:growing in our power. When I first e26:started just six years ago, it was unusual to e27:have a woman e1000014:managing a bill."

Just as important, even male senators say, is the potential the women e29:hold for e30:changing the tenor of the Senate and e31:pushing for compromise in the highly partisan atmosphere on Capitol Hill.

"I don't e32:want to e33:generalize, because this isn't true of all of them, but they tend to be interested in finding common ground," e36:said Senator Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio. "So I e37:think it's going to e38:have, and is e1000015:having, a positive e39:impact on the Senate."

As Ms. Ayotte, a freshman Republican from New Hampshire, e4:sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had e5:cast their votes, a doorman e6:marched toward her with purpose.

The desks, he sternly e7:told her, were for senators only.

Ms. Ayotte's e1000010:induction that January day in 2011 into the most rarefied ranks of the nation's political class, female senators, had e8:begun. "The desk thing really e9:stuck with me," Ms. Ayotte e10:said. "There still just aren't that many of us."

In the 90 years since Rebecca Felton of Georgia e11:became the first woman in the United States Senate - e12:sworn in for a mere 24 hours - women e13:remain an anomaly in the upper chamber. But with 20 female senators now in e1000011:office, an all-time high, women have e1000012:morphed from the e1010:curiosity they were for much of the 20th century into an important new force on key committees and legislation.

A record nine women now lead committees, including some of the most powerful ones. For the first time there is a woman - Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat - in charge of the Senate Appropriations Committee, which e14:dispenses billions of dollars annually throughout the government and has long been particularly e15:dominated by men. Senator Patty Murray, a Washington Democrat, is the first chairwoman of the Budget Committee and is e16:charged with e17:shaping the Democratic strategy in the fiscal e18:battle dominating Capitol Hill.

One of the biggest bills to e19:pass the Senate last year was farm legislation e20:led by Senator Debbie Stabenow, a Michigan Democrat who e21:presides over the agriculture committee. Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat who is chairwoman of the Environment and Public Works Committee, e22:shepherded the highway bill.

"We are e23:growing in number," e24:said Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota. "But more importantly, we are e25:growing in our power. When I first e26:started just six years ago, it was unusual to e27:have a woman e1000014:managing a bill."

Just as important, even male senators say, is the potential the women e29:hold for e30:changing the tenor of the Senate and e31:pushing for compromise in the highly partisan atmosphere on Capitol Hill.

"I don't e32:want to e33:generalize, because this isn't true of all of them, but they tend to be interested in finding common ground," e36:said Senator Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio. "So I e37:think it's going to e38:have, and is e1000015:having, a positive e39:impact on the Senate."

While partisan division is the central characteristic of the modern Congress, women have e40:begun to e41:crack away at the e1003:gridlock by e42:forming coalitions that have e1000016:surprised leaders of both parties. Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, and Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, e43:led the e44:repeal in the Senate of "don't ask, don't tell" in 2010, e47:allowing gay men and women to e48:serve openly in the military.

text:
Before the e1:arrival of Keep, which Google e3:launched this week, there was no default note-taking app for Android. It was a glaring hole, considering that Apple's iPhone e5:has built-in Notes and Reminders apps that can be e6:powered by Siri.

Instead of e7:settling for a bare bones app to e8:fill the void, the search giant e9:took things one step further. Keep isn't simply just a place to bank whatever random half-thoughts come to mind: Users can construct to-do lists, stash photos, and color code your notes -- all in one well-designed and easy-to-use interface.

The second you log anything into your phone, it is also accessible from a PC Web browser via Google Drive. Alternatively, you can save things while working on your computer, and it will instantly appear on your phone, ready for use while on the go.

The design may not be as progressive as the to-do app Clear, but Keep makes up for that in its simplicity and efficiency.

Everything in Keep is presented like a Microsoft (MSFT, Fortune 500) Windows Phone-esque stream of tiles. Swiping left or right will archive those notes you no longer need (but don't want to erase entirely). At the top of the app is a text entry field that serves as your main point of entry for all new notes. And when viewing any specific note, tapping any part of that note (title, body, etc.) will allow you to edit it. The entire experience is frictionless.

That said, it's not going to e30:conquer the world quite yet. Organization options are limited -- color coding is your only choice, and you can't re-order your notes. Sharing with others is mostly limited to email and Google+, and the desktop features are pretty bare bones.

But that's more a function of it being new, rather than poorly thought out. Like most things Google, e35:expect the company to e45:flesh out Keep over time and really e36:turn it into our personal internet junk drawer.

It's easy to e37:foresee the day the when users will be able to e38:send anything from their Web browser or Maps directly to Keep. The prospect of Keep e46:incorporating features of services such as Pinterest or Pocket, or even making it easy to catalog streaming media, could e40:turn it into something big. That should e41:scare Evernote.

Keep is not the e49:reinvention of the wheel in any aspect -- there are a plethora of third-party apps already e50:available for Android. But it is a well-exectuted refinement.

In e42:filling a minor, but important gap in its mobile ecosystem, Google e43:gives the competition one less claim of superiority over Android.

text:
China's state leadership e43:transition has e1:taken place this month against an ominous backdrop. More than 16,000 dead pigs have been e2:found e3:floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai. A haze akin to volcanic fumes e4:cloaked the capital, e5:causing convulsive e6:coughing and e7:obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City.

So severe are China's environmental woes, especially the noxious air, that top government officials have been e8:forced to openly e9:acknowledge them. Fu Ying, the spokeswoman for the National People's Congress, e10:said she e11:checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and e13:kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself. Li Keqiang, the new prime minister, e14:said the air pollution had e15:made him "quite e44:upset" and e16:vowed to "e17:show even greater resolve and make more vigorous e19:efforts" to e20:clean it up.

Last month, after deadly air pollution e21:hit record levels in northern China, officials e22:led byWen Jiabao, then the prime minister, e23:put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years. But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will e24:comply, especially since oil officials e25:resisted a similar government order for higher-grade fuel four years ago. State-owned power companies have been similarly e46:resistant. The companies regularly ignore government orders to e26:upgrade coal-burning electricity plants, e27:according to ministry data. And as with the oil companies, the power companies e28:exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates.

In 2011, during a round of e29:discussions over stricter emissions standards, the China Electricity Council, which represents the companies, e30:pushed back hard against the proposals, e31:saying that the costs of e32:upgrading the plants would be too high.

On Feb. 28, Deutsche Bank e33:released an analysts' note e34:saying that China's current economic policies would e35:result in an enormous e36:surge in coal e47:consumption and automobile e48:sales over the next decade. "China's air pollution will e37:become a lot worse from the already unbearable level," the analysts e38:said, e39:calling for drastic policy e49:changes and "a strong government will to e40:overcome the opposition from interest groups."

The report e41:estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit e42:400 million by 2030, up from e1000:90 million now.

Fu Ying, the spokeswoman for the National People's Congress, e10:said she e11:checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and e13:kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself. Last month, after deadly air pollution e21:hit record levels in northern China, officials e22:led byWen Jiabao, then the prime minister, e23:put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years. But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will e24:comply, especially since oil officials e25:resisted a similar government order for higher-grade fuel four years ago. text:
Our digital age is all about bits, those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code.

But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially e1:deployed by a major American military contractor is e2:taking computing into the strange, subatomic realm of quantum mechanics. In that infinitesimal neighborhood, common sense logic no longer seems to apply. A one can be a one, or it can be a one and a zero and everything in between  all at the same time.

It sounds preposterous, particularly to those familiar with the yes/no world of conventional computing. But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft, I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard have been e6:working to e7:develop quantum computers.

Now, Lockheed Martin  which e8:bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D-Wave Systems two years ago  is e9:confident enough in the technology to e10:upgrade it to commercial scale, e11:becoming the first company to e12:use quantum computing as part of its business.

Skeptics e14:say that D-Wave has yet to e15:prove to outside scientists that it has e16:solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation.

But if it e18:performs as Lockheed and D-Wave e19:expect, the design could be e20:used to e21:supercharge even the most powerful systems, e22:solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be e23:done today.

Ray Johnson, Lockheeds chief technical officer, e24:said his company would e25:use the quantum computer to e26:create and e27:test complex radar, space and aircraft systems. It could be possible, for example, to e28:tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would e29:react to a solar e30:burst or a e31:pulse from a nuclear explosion  something that can now take weeks, if ever, to e33:determine.

The last surviving member of the team which first e1:conquered Everest in 1953 has e2:died in a Derbyshire nursing home.

George Lowe, 89, e3:died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long-term e45:illness, with his wife Mary by his side.

New Zealand-born Mr Lowe was part of the team that e4:helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953.

Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis-Jones e6:paid tribute to a "gentle soul and fine climber" who e7:shunned the limelight.

Mr Lowe also e8:took part in the trans-Antarctic e9:expedition of 1957-58, which e10:made the first successful overland e11:crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole.

He later e12:made e13:expeditions to Greenland, Greece and Ethiopia.

Speaking to the BBC in 1995, Mr Lowe e14:said of his Antarctic adventure: "We e15:estimated we could e16:do it in 100 days, and we e17:got across on the 99th day.

"There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone. It e18:had a multiplying effect.

"We were e19:pleased that England and New Zealand e20:knew about it, and we e21:thought that's where it would e22:stop."

He also e23:talked about his "second job" as the group's cameraman, and having to e24:wear four pairs of gloves to e25:work the clockwork camera.

Dr Lewis-Jones, the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge, who first e29:met Mr Lowe in 2005, e30:called him a "hero".

"I don't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one," he e34:said.

He e36:said: "Lowe was a brilliant, kind fellow who never e37:sought the limelight... and 60 years on from e54:Everest his achievements e38:deserve wider recognition.

"He was e39:involved in two of the most important e56:explorations of the 20th Century... yet e40:remained a humble, happy man right to the e2000:end... an inspirational lesson to us all."

Before e41:retiring in 1984, Mr Lowe e42:worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences, and he e43:leaves three sons from a previous e57:marriage.

Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis-Jones e6:paid tribute to a "gentle soul and fine climber" who e7:shunned the limelight.

Mr Lowe also e8:took part in the trans-Antarctic e9:expedition of 1957-58, which e10:made the first successful overland e11:crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole.

He later e12:made e13:expeditions to Greenland, Greece and Ethiopia.

Speaking to the BBC in 1995, Mr Lowe e14:said of his Antarctic adventure: "We e15:estimated we could e16:do it in 100 days, and we e17:got across on the 99th day.
